reviewText:
Full disclosure: I bought this game at 96% off, for fifteen pence. And even at that price, I would not recommend buying this game.

This game in a word? Unrealised. The actual game has two themes -- the first being a fairly generic 'your actions have moral consequences' theme that's used extremely simplistically by giving an occasional yes/no choice, and the second being age, which is dealt with only in an exceedingly shallow capacity. While both of these themes can be compelling when written sufficiently well, the more unique and interesting one is age; most people playing videogames are fairly young or approaching middle age, so age is a topic that gets swept under the rug or only dealt with as a way to get rid of a character in most games. Given a nuanced portrayal, it could have been excellent here. It wasn't.

In terms of gameplay, it has the standard non-combat rpg maker formula -- wander around, talk to people, get information, solve puzzles. Most rpg maker games will attempt to flavour their world beyond the basic graphics by giving interesting flavour text on clickable items, a feature I adore. True, this game does have many clickable items, and a lot of flavour text... but all of it is either very bland descriptions of what you're looking at, or immature flavour text.

Actually, let's cycle back to the immature bit. Do you think naked pixelated old men are funny? Do you think it's great that a good portion of your game world is compared to poo? Because that's why some of the steam pages related to this game ask for age confirmation, and the devs never seem to get tired of it. It's pretty much worthless in terms of content, both comedically and in terms of worldbuilding. It just makes the game seem like it was made by juvenile teenagers.

The writing, outside of the themes it tries and fails to tackle, is uninspiring. NPCs are both unlikeable and boring, as, in fact, are all the player characters. There simply isn't enough dialogue given -- in a format, mind you, that really *needs* dialogue and description in order to be effective -- to characterise even one of the protagonists beyond a very simple pastiche of whatever their problem is. I feel like the dev(s?) of this game aren't really familiar with creating works of art or fiction -- although, as a plus, I only noticed one glaring grammar problem (an NPC using were" when the correct version for the context would have been "where." reviewText:
Greyfox is a short and sweet little game made in RPG Maker, thugh I'd not call it an RPG since it really is more of a point and click adventure type of game.  The premise is really interestng as it is modern day.

You play as a young girl looking to better her life.  She quits her job and moves to a town called Greyfox with no promise of a new job or even a place to live.  Then you meet a strange woman who tries to deter her from staying and she leads the main character through a set of dreams where she gets to live the lives of other people in the town.

Good points:
+Interesting premise
+The four characters your main character gets to walk around as are interesting.
+Lot of stuff to discover and people to talk to, obvious care was taken at constructing this little town.
+Multiple endings

Neutral points:
*Rather short, I was able to get all the achievements in less than two hours

Not so good points:
-The main character really was lacking in any characterization
-The characters whose lives you lived were in some cases very stereotypical elderly people even if they were interesting.

Overall though, I'd recommend the game.  It's short and simple, but also not very pricey.  It's definitely a game to pick up and play and you can easily finish in one game session.  The premise is definitely unique and a refreshing change.

reviewText:
Greyfox is a story about a woman who 'takes control' of her life and moves to a new town. There she meets a rather interesting woman who gives her the power to make decisions. Depending on the decisions you make, determines how the story ends.

The game is built upon the idea of taknig a look at 4 different people's lives that could be viewed on the surface as kind of bad. There is a good little bit of detail in this one town game that changes based on which life you are exploring. While some of the assets are stock, it really doesn't make much of a difference, the stories are interesting enough that you don't really notice them unless you really care about that sort of thing.

The Achievements are pretty easy to get, and seeing the different endings is actually interesting. The music is pretty good, but depending on how long you play could get irritating. Most importantly, the dialogue in the game is pretty good. You can tell the authors put some thought into the game.

I would recommend it if you have time for a short 2 hour game to explore, unless you aren't interested in the concept. There are no battles, do don't get your hopes up. This is not a traditional RPG Maker game.

One tiny gripe is the devs couldn't figure out how to make F12 not reset the game to the title screen. No screenshots for you. :/

Overall for the price tag it carries, it's worth getting and playing.

For an RPG Maker game definite 6/10

reviewText:
Greyfox is sort of a role playing game... in that you assume the roles of various characters throughout the game. It's basically like a point and click adventure type game, but instead of pointing and clicking you have RPG type controls and environments. The basic plot is that you, the main character, get sick of your day to day life. You decide to quit your job and move to the small town of Greyfox, which is inhabited mainly by elderly people. You quickly get into a scenario where you are forced to live a day in the life of someone in town. This happens multiple times. This is essentially all you do in the game, without going into spoiler terrirory about what happens with each character.

The gameplay, as mentioned, is basically going around, examining the environments, talking to people, getting items, and trying to use items to complete tasks within the game. Some things can be missed but others are necessary to progress. You will get to pick different options in some dialogues. The answers sometimes have consequences and sometimes don't matter. At the end of each day, you get to decide whether the character you've played as lives or dies. After all the days, there's a final cutscene and the game ends.

I liked how the game played, as opposed to actual point and click games. The RPG playstyle and art style helped me get into it more than some visual novel or point and click adventure normally would. I also like how the game gives you choices that may or may not matter. In fact, and this may be a bit of a spoiler but it doesn't really matter ultimately, in the end all of your choices have no true consequences aside from how you personally feel about them. This is a pretty cool idea, to let you feel how you want to about what you've chosen as the fate of these people. The way you play is determined by your own set of values moreso than those of the developers. It's also nice to play some depressing games now and then. It's not necessarily a happy ending, but it can be as long as you feel like it is. It's just a neat little concept.

On the downside, there's also no true goal of this game. The rather aimless nature is strung along by a few integral decidions that you have to make and actions you have to do in order to move on. You can't really lose the game. So there's no real goal here. There IS replay value to see what happens if you do different things, but there's not a lot of incentive when it goes against your own values to make such choices, especially in a game that is so fueled on such choices. Also, many times during the game certain places will be closed off to you. This doesn't feel like it's all that natural. It just seems like they didn't program interesting things in those areas for the entire game so only areas where you'd need to go are programmed in. It's okay, but feels a little lacking and as though it's trying to herd you in the right direction... in a game that's about exploring the world in other people's shoes. Also, a minor complain about the art. I like it, but it seems like a lot of it is just assests from some RPG maker. Not a big deal in terms of the story and atmosphere, but still a little lazy on some of it.

Overall? Greyfox is a fun, interesting little game. It'll probably only last you one to two hours to finish... which means you'll either want to achievement hunt or idle it to get the card drops. It's not for everyone, and I wouldn't call it an RPG, but if you like the concept of exploring the lives of old people and choosing their fate, then look into it. Is it worth the full 5 bucks? I would say no, personally. BUT, if you can get it for around 50 cents or less, it's definitely worth a shot. Maybe a dollar if you're really interested. It's just not long enough or deep enough to be worth full price. Greyfox gets a 5 out of 10 for being a fun, interesting little adventure where personal values and investment in the characters really pay off.

I tend to look twice before I buy a game made with RPG Maker, since the production value can vary greatly from experience. This title was a bit of a special case though, since it played more like a linear novel than a traditional RPG.

First of all there are no combat scenes, and by extension, no level ups to speak of. There is an inventory of sorts, but what you get is mostly linear to the plot progression. The game play lasts around two hours or so and there is a lot of talking involved, if visual novels are not your cup of tea, this won’t fare much better for you.

If you’re willing to look past the strange design choices, or the mediocre range of sprites used, you’ll probably get to enjoy the storyline as I did; which was a decent mix between the slice-of-life and supernatural genres.

Lastly, I regret to say that the game has zero replay value beyond the different endings, but it was memorable for the duration, no matter how short it was. I would recommend this to others, though only if you have nothing else to play on your backlog.

reviewText:
A nice little adventure game.You play a young woman who quits your job to move to a retirement town called Greyfox, seemingly because you've had it with life and want to take things slow and easy. Upon moving to Greyfox, you encounter a mysterious woman who brings you on a rather unique and interesting adventure.

High on exploration.This isn't your conventional RPG, in that no battles are involved. Instead, this is much more like a regular adventure game, except you move around and interact using the keyboard instead of mouse. There are many different locations to check out even though the story only ever takes place in the town of Greyfox, and every location is visually a joy to process.

High on detail and humour.Almost everything (from people to objects) in this cute little pixel world can be clicked on to yield elaborate - and in many cases, humorous - descriptions. There are also many optional extras or bonuses to be gleaned from exploring as much as you can. E.g. I found it a delight to randomly dig into some seats and find cash!

High on choice.Lots of instances where you must make decisions. In at least several of them, these decisions will result in a different ending. So there's a degree of replayability involved - choose different paths the next round to get different results.

A pleasure to play.In case you need more convincing, check out my screenshots here.

reviewText:
According to the ending credits, Greyfox was created in a program called ‘RPG Maker’—a program from which Greyfox derives nearly all of its assets. It’s a lazily-designed, glorified point-and-click game dressed up as a proper role-playing game that provides a mere semblance of an actual narrative concept. The game tells the story of the residents of Greyfox—a small town inhabited mostly by the elderly and named after the big stone statue of a fox in the centre of the little village. Everyone in town seems to openly aggressive towards the player, which the game is quick to point out is as a result of their age. For some reason.

Throughout the game’s short story—I saw all three endings in under two hours—age seems to be the primary theme, though none of the endings have anything to do with this. Honestly, the entire plot is a meandering, disjointed mess with no proper focus and excessive use of ex machinas do drive the proceedings. The decisions you make essentially come down to either killing a person or not killing them, with the only impact being different ending cinematics. Maybe Greyfox could win a short story contest hosted by a primary school, but as a game it’s just a frustrating mess.

In regards to gameplay, Greyfox does initially start out with a mildly interesting element of exploration. You’re presented with the eponymous town and encouraged to just explore, which is fun for a few minutes, until you realise the map is approximately the size of the average grocery store, and is filled with random NPCs who yell at you for talking to them. The game completely fails to capitalise on the sense of discovery it almost establishes, instead railroading you down a ludicrously linear corridor of short, hastily written dialogue which relies heavily on exposition. The gameplay itself is about as organic and enjoyable as checking items of a shopping list—talk to someone, then go to a specific building and click on a specific item and then go back and talk to the same person. It’s a rinse and repeat formula from which next to no enjoyment could be derived.

There’s not much else to say about Greyfox, because there’s very little to say in the first place. It’s a tiny game with no proper story or gameplay that’s really best avoided. Some may appreciate its focus on emotion, but it is no more than a short and lacklustre experience.

Preface
Greyfox Review... the first one I do in English

I've experienced some Maker-games so far and can say that I mostly look at an interesting setting or storyline before I mention to buy it or to play it. For most games in this genre there is a special way how I evaluate Maker-games, but instead of showing you this list (I didn't ever wrote it down anyway) I will take this game as example...

Content
The little driving part in the first minutes of gameplay was well designed, also was the town Greyfox. You can interact with almost every item in this game and get one or two lines with a good description about it. And then there was some hilarious moments and little details I enjoyed. But unfortunately - the game is short. One single hour in fact. But because it has three different endings it is worth to re-play it... atleast one time I think.

Besides the driving part (with way too stupid AI and bad mechanics), gameplay is more offside the road. You get some little side-quests here and there, rewarded with an achievement and that's it. No mini games or puzzles... unfortunately.

But where it really leaks, is the story. The fact that you can play as different charakters and judge over their misdeeds whether they should kill themselfes or not is quite enjoyable... but was it really necessary? Killing or leaving those people doesn't feel right. What if you were able to save everyone and fix their lives again (active)... Speak to your family, show them that you aren't just an eldery ♥♥♥♥ in a retirement home... Have a last day together with your poisoned husband to bring love to 'em - a last time again. Maybe it is kitchy but better than just leave them and forget them again. I mean you won't ever get any clues how you were able to do this or why you were chosen to do so. It doesn't feel alive or reasoned. So why not? At the end it's better than nothing.

Conclusion

Price: Okay -> You got your money spent on two or three hours; one filled with the actual story, the last one is probably filled with skipping text massages to gain the rest of the achievements... maybe wait for a sale.

Rating: Average -> What is there more to say? We have a interesting setting but no answers to the story... you want more in the end and unfortunately there was so much potentioal wasted... that's why for me it's just an ordinary game. Go for the achievements if you want, or else, just leave it.

reviewText:
TL;DR:  I give Greyfox a 2-out-of-10, but it's still worth looking at
Now, I bought this game at 96% off, and I think it's worth about that.  If you like seeing an unusual mechanic used in an RPG, you'll want to look at this; otherwise, you can skip it.
This review will have minor spoilers throughout, but I don't think they're the sort that should ruin any of the story.
After all, the storytelling mostly ruins itself.

So, you're a fairly young woman (it looks that way, anyway) who hates her life, and decides to fix that by quitting her job to move to an old folks' retirement community named Greyfox.  Arriving with no money at all, she picks up dog poop, rummages through seat cushions, steals jewelry, and buys grapes to pay for her hotel room.  But our hero gets to play, too:  after wrecking an old lady's flower garden, she gets one of the more interesting characters arrested for questionable business practices.  Was it for ethics or just lulz?  [whynotboth.jpg]  (The truth?  In this game, probably neither.)  Then a mystical Marla Singer From Fight Club shows up and gives your protagonist the power to possess geezers' bodies and kill them off.

The best of the game's humor is in the story above.  There's other jokes that are okay, but mostly it's about poop and rather repetitive.

What makes this game special is the way it has you play the different roles.  I'm sure other games have done it (Live A Live from SNES is the closest game that comes to mind), but it's a delightful mechanic to see, and worth trying this game out just to see it.  The story arcs are short and mediocre, and desperately beg for being re-written with some depth.  The important dialog options are yes/no choices that totally prevent an in-depth analysis of morality that the game needs.

The flavor text, like of the plants, and the hidden items -- random stuff behind pillars, etc. -- are nice, but really make you wonder what the writers thought their game was supposed to be.  For a story and gameplay that's essentially all about morality and mortality, and appears to delve into deep matters, that's really all quite superficial.  The utter lack of nuance in dealing with aging is baffling (I feel like more needs to be said, but I don't know what to say:  I really mean baffling").  You can tell what the author's real interests were:  more thought was put into the unique descriptions of plants in the game than into the philosophy that the game seems to revolve around

reviewText:
Greyfox! What a great game! Except it is way too short. I see a very bright future for the developers of this game. I beat the game in 69 minutes, and it might take you up to 2 hours to get all the 16 achievements.

The game has a great story! Very interesting, and really just outright good. The gameplay isn't much. It's just walking around and interacting. Now the story is about the main character (which surprisingly, or not, I thought was a boy) and this mysterious witch-like character which makes the main character think about how horrible life is. You live in the lives of 4 different old people and experience their lives.

Now, the game is truly an RPG game. You can do things ranging from stealing and old man's watch all the way down to commiting suicide as an old lady, you can do whatever you want. Moslty. Well, only if the game gives you the choice.

I managed to get this game for 15p. For 15p, it is cheaper than all arcade games I know of and much longer. I mean, you can die in an arcade game, while here it's mostly about the story. The graphics are retro styled which is... okay. It is certainly understandable since it is easy to do for most developers.

If this game developer can continue to bring these great story-based games down to us, the gamers, then they'd do a good job and I'd probably buy their games all the time (as long as the reviews state positiveness).

I believe you should totally give this game a try, BUT ONLY ON SALE. ONLY AT 15p will this game be worth it. If a little longer, about 4 hours, and other stuff to do then it might truly be worth it. But that's too late anyway.
I might've scared you off, but trust me, this game is incredible and I loved 2/3 of the game. One thing I have to point out is that you're driving a BMW in the beginning for about 1 ~ 2 minutes and the car drives badly. Very badly. It is as fast, or slow, as your main character whilst walking. It's like one of those Java games you'd get on a Samsung Tocco.

Get this game. But only on sale. I enjoyed the music, the story, the dialogue between some characters, etc.

EDIT --

Mind you, it is going to take you just around 4 hours to get all achievements since you have to replay the game numerous times to get the different endings.

reviewText:
“Good writing is supposed to evoke sensation in the reader-not the fact that it is raining, but the feeling of being rained upon.” -E.L. DoctorowWith a style reminiscent of classic roleplaying titles, Greyfox is a story-driven game in which players control a young woman who has just recently retired from her career to live in the modest town of, aptly named, Greyfox. This game was created with RPG Maker and involves making difficult decisions while progressing, and with much more to discover throughout the township. Though rather short in duration, it is quite enjoyable, and the dialogue is impressive.
Here are a few items that I enjoyed and found compelling about Greyfox:

Story - As explained, Greyfox is centered around a young woman who is relieving herself from work for the final time to retire in a the remote town of Greyfox. The player discovers secrets within the community, as well as between its members, in a well-written adventure that spans over several periods; the dialogue and themes are fluid and interlock appropriately. This title has multiple endings and subsequent consequences depending on what the player decides to do throughout its advancement. *I do not wish to reveal too much about the story, but please reveal the spoiler text if you would like to know more a little more* As the said character, the player takes control of four elderly individuals with distinct destinies. The player then discovers the dim mysteries of each elderly individual while also completing side quests involved in the other characters’ arcs.

Hidden Content - From its side objectives to its references, unlike many Indie titles, Greyfox’s composition is established on subtlety. Because of this, exploration is highly encouraged; the game only takes about an hour to complete the story entirely while interacting with most things in the world, but there is so much more to unearth in the relationships between the various people and timelines.

Dialogue - Greyfox, since there are no complex mechanics other than its sense of choice, heavily relies on spoken and written word. In a sense, there is a purpose and comment for and from each non-player character in this title which really entices the player to inquire from others within the world to not only progress, but to also simply enjoy what is said. As stated previously and emphasized by the opening quote, Greyfox empowers the player when it should and shuts them down when applicable; it has some powerful writing, which compliments the playstyle well. It is humorous, fun, grim, and intelligent at the points it is necessary to be.

TL:DR - Beginning this title, I was skeptical with the story hook. However, it did not take long for the lore to engulf my entirety, as I interacted with nearly everything I could with glee simply to see what text would appear from either the author or the individual being spoken to. This title is extremely cheap but easy to finish totally, and is generally fun and thought-provoking throughout. I would highly recommend this title for those who enjoy story-based games as well as simple roleplaying games with choice-related elements. Thanks for reading.

reviewText:
Short version: 71%Greyfox is a short, depressing anthology about growing old and miserable with a few interesting tales and thankfully no preachy attitude. It’s worth its price if you are into fanfic style stories.

Long version:Made by a group of enthusiastic young artists, Greyfox is an anthology made on the popular RPG Maker game engine, about the concept of growing old and how most people feel about their aging.

These tales are told through the eyes of an energetic young woman who moves to the titular town, Greyfox, with the hopes of starting a new, exciting life there. But she soon finds out the town is full of grumpy old people, and with a help of an unexplained mystic, she manages to take control of four of them.
The scenarios after that try to tell you how not to grow miserable by your old age, further emphasised with the option to give a verdict on the lives you intrude on. This message is not always easy to spot under the clunky dialogues, but it is there.

Don’t expect detailed and complex stories; unless you get lost, the entire game can be finished in about 30-45 minutes– 60-70, if you want to see all endings. Still, it’s cheap, and gives as much entertainment as one would expect for this price.

First impressions of this game looked promising, but expectations fall short and it turns out to be disappointing in terms of hype the creators of this game made it looked like in their description.
I’ve played many times both Chrono Trigger and Final Fantasy VI, completed them several times as well, and to say that Greyfox is inspired in their style... seems a bit boastful in my opinion

Story

Your story begin at the controls of an unnamed female protagonist who just decides to up and leave, quits the job that she claims makes her miserable and moves to the small town of Greyfox, whose population mainly consists of old grumpy people. After doing a bit of exploring around town, talking to the residents, you come across a mysterious woman who talks about seeing life through someone else’s eyes, then she vanishes. Not thinking any further of this, you head to your room at the inn to turn in for the night.

As you wake up, you find yourself in a strange place with that mysterious lady. Your “heroine” is suddenly all wrinkled up and confuse about what happened to her. The mysterious lady will then ask you how you feel about old age, one of the main theme this game keep bringing up. Depending on your answer, you will taking be at the control of some of the resident of Greyfox, seeing what they see and deciding of their fates.

Design

As you will quickly notice, this game is pretty basic when it comes to a RPG maker spawn. A few element look like customized assets but there’s not too many of them. The town itself is small, but beautiful. Greyfox is the only area where you’ll be traveling into, aside for the little street map that precedes you entering the town, you’re boxed in there.

UI are kept to a minimum with only an inventory box, and an option to save and quit the game. There also a window to keep track of your cash, but given how little use it has through the game, its almost useless.

While this game is fairly short and easy to complete, it does offer multiple endings. Your actions throughout the game’s course will dictate which ending you will be getting. Seeing all the endings will require 3 playthroughs. Before you claim that it will be a daunting task to accomplish, just note you can see it all and obtain all the achievements in less than 2 hours. Your first run of the game might take you longer if you chose to fully explore and interact with everyone and everything, but after that, you can just go for the story triggers and finish this game in about 30 minutes or less.

As the author mentioned on the kickstarter page for this project, the concept inspiration came from their own life, living in a “retirement” town similar to what depicted in the game. What disappoints me is that this game could have been a great thing, it seem full of potential,  it touches on topics not often bought up in video games, but alas after playing through multiples times to get all the achievement, it felt lackluster.  The characters may have been inspired by real-life people, but here they felt generic and lacking depth. Each character could had a much deeper story, more events to unravel. Instead we just get treated to a point and click visual novel.

Gameplay

Greyfox is your non-combat flavor of RPG. So no random battles, grinding, dungeons or challenging boss battles. Instead you take control of four different town residents and guide them through their “tough” choice. By tough choice, i mean a decision between yes and no more oft than not. Do you put your avatar out of their misery by killing them off or do you let Father Time take care of it for you. Certainly brings a question of morality but given how bland and shallow they are scripted, you barely get any attachment to any of them. If killing them off meant to bring a shock value of any kind, it missed its mark by a long shot.

You can interact with just about any object found in the game which is good to see that a lot effort went into making this possible. If you’re looking to get all the achievement, you will need to check everywhere for hidden stuff. Some items found make getting some achievements impossible to attain unless you get them. Overall this might prolong the duration of your first run of the game, but ultimately  it acts like filler to give you something else to do in this short game rather than always going from point A to point B.

The effort put in this project is real, but somehow, it feels more like a PSA to raise awareness on how many seniors people can have it difficult in their old age, rather than a video game. It does a good job at this. Most people probably know an old scrooge who hates and is hated by everyone around him, or that crazy cat lady who just seems even crazier when she’s off her meds.

Final Thoughts

Regardless of what ending you get, it all seems like it was all a dream. The good ending sees you waking up in your bedroom to the sound of a blaring alarm clock. The bad ending sees you locked in the loony bin, perhaps because killing all these people in your dream snapped your sanity last straw. The so-so ending finds you in therapy with a psychiatrist who believes you imagined everything and the town of Greyfox might just be a figment of your vivid imagination and ups the dosage of your medication.

Regardless of its brevity, Greyfox did entertain me for a little while, if you like a short story game that doesn’t require to much thinking to get through, then you’d probably like this game. You don’t need to be a hardcore completionist to get all the achievements, a few might be a bit cryptic at first, but just in case you’re stumped you can always check out the guide in the community section.

With this in mind, I give this game a final rating of 6/10

For 5 U.S. dollars you can get a lot of things. A music CD from a superstore, some food, maybe some fruit juice. But what about 5 unique perspectives on growing older and dealing with it? That kind of thing doesn't come cheap, but that's exactly what this game provides. I got this game for mere cents on sale, and I'd say I payed too little. While Greyfox is an RPG, it's more like a visual novel in a RPG style. Frankly, I really like that. I enjoy RPG stylization, but not some RPG elements generally. Greyfox makes the best with the limits of RPG Maker, and stands out as a unique title with a extremely thought-provoking story.

Overview: Greyfox is a short point-and-click (without the click) adventure game. You take on the role of a young woman who is fed up with life in the big city and decides to move to a sleepy little town called Greyfox. However, shortly after arrival, you find yourself learning more about certain members of the community than you ever thought possible.

Plot: The plot is simple but creative. You take on the lives of some of the townsfolk, granting you the ability to make a critical decision for each of the four residents you play as. I really like the concept, and the fact that there multiple endings depending on your choices, but I feel like they definitely could have taken it a step further. Only one of the four characters gives you an additional decision, although it has no bearing on the ending. It would have been nice to expand range of influence you have over more minor decisions and see those choices reflected in the ending. The endings, too, leave something to be desired. They consist of very short cutscenes that briefly depict how your decisions ultimately affected you. While you do get a snippet about each of the characters you played as, I think it would have been more interesting to have a couple of additional cutscenes from their perspectives or that of their familes/friends/townsfolk.

Graphics/Interface: The graphics aren’t the super high quality stuff that many of the top video games feature, but it’s certainly not a drawback. The town of Greyfox is cute and set up with consideration that encourages – and sometimes demands – careful exploration of your surroundings. I personally found the controls a little bizarre, using the arrow keys/enter after being so used to WASD/mouse, but it’s not a big deal.

Replay Value: The alternate endings provide at least three iterations of the game – more if you missed certain achievements. However, once you’ve played through all the possibilities (~2 hours, maybe more if you’re struggling to nab those last couple achievements and you’re determined not to look it up), you’re probably not going to play it again.

My recommendation: It’s an interesting premise and perfect if you don’t have the time to get sucked into a really involved game. I bought it on sale for $0.19, and for 2 hours of entertainment, I think it was worth it. I personally wouldn’t spend $5 on it, though.
